Tense yet invigorating, The Bourne Ultimatum presents a terrific argument for the nonstop-action summer movie. Even those rare moments when it slows down offer more excitement than other films' full-bore action scenes.
Cheadle makes all these things believable within the same person while showing how being pulled in several directions wears on Petey.
Essentially an episode of the long-running Fox hit, just extended and writ larger.
When aunt and niece eventually bond, the moment is truly affecting. But the length of time it takes to get there underscores how thin this story is.
A lively, engaging and sweet-natured movie musical.

A certain majesty is conveyed by the cinematic largess. In three dimensions, the imperial nature of the lion is fleshed out. It's akin to the difference between seeing a magazine photograph of a lion and encountering one at the zoo.
[The filmmakers] keep Order of the Phoenix consistently involving. But it's Radcliffe who truly shines here.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cars turn into robots. So do trucks. And planes. If you need more to recommend Transformers, there are big doses of humor and an appealing lead performance by Shia LaBeouf.
The tone, in turn, moves from arch to soapy to poignant. Yet it's the story that one can never quite get one's arms around.
Filled with personal stories, the picture jolts us back into awareness and outrage. Yet it's also Moore's most widely relatable film.
Ratatouille might be that rare G-rated film that adults enjoy even more than children. In other words, some scenes cater to folks who prefer truffles over goldfish crackers.

A film whose story is framed by tragedy and the haunting human obsession that followed it. And that's what makes its stunning and highly vertiginous visuals all the more dramatic and relevant to the non-climber.
Willis and Berry's joint star power makes their exchanges at least moderately interesting. But their characters' supposed banter never reaches wittiness, and the cat-and-mouse angle is too mild.

Disturbia seems unsure whether to be a creepy thriller, a drama or a coming-of-age comedy. What's certain about this well-acted, visually assured movie is that, scene by scene, it's often lively and engaging.
You can see the love in every frame.
Letters From Iwo Jima, director Clint Eastwood's look at the World War II battle from the perspective of the Japanese forces, is more accomplished and moving than Eastwood's Flags of Our Fathers.
The sheer force and fearlessness of Dench's performance is something to behold, as Barbara's deeply ingrained class and personal resentments mix with a discomfiting neediness.
Technically magnificent and flawlessly acted, the picture incorporates 20th century Spanish history and classic fairy-tale elements in a way that seems completely new.
[The] performances help director Todd Field (In the Bedroom) calibrate a masterful mix of humor, tragedy and heavy stylization.
This adaptation of the W. Somerset Maugham novel contains more anger and sexuality -- altogether more passion -- than other beautifully appointed period films of its class.
Children of Men so thoroughly captivates visually that one can forgive the film's tendency to explain itself only vaguely.
Sometimes a splashy movie musical can be just the thing.

The Good Shepherd does contain occasional tense moments and threatens, at points, to blossom into an actual thriller. But instead, it remains a character study of a character who is frustratingly hard to read.
This particular movie, obviously carefully and thoroughly researched, needed to articulate the experiences of the townspeople of Huntington more thoroughly than it does.
Sylvester Stallone, 60, still looks great with his shirt off. It's his directing, writing and acting skills that at times seem out of shape.
Appaloosa carries a whiff of feminism. Or at least an awareness of what life was like for women on the frontier.

It's the picture's lifelike approach, from the immediacy of Italian director Gabriele Muccino's use of a handheld camera to screenwriter Steven Conrad's keen sense of the little things that make or break a day, that renders it truly moving.
Blood Diamond takes its title from jewels sold to fund murder and mayhem in conflict zones. Yet it's not a message movie but an old-fashioned, entertaining action adventure that contains messages.

Winslet gets time to build a lovable, kind character. In the process, the English actress known for serious roles shows she can handle just about any part -- even one in a formulaic American romantic comedy -- with exceptional grace.
The seamlessness of the actors' performances underscores Gibson's directing skills.
Shows [Black] at his comic best -- overly enthusiastic and quick to anger without ever becoming a buffoon.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Jane Lynch and Fred Willard are consistent bright spots as "Entertainment Tonight"-style bozo TV hosts fanning the flames of Purim fever.
Cheesy at moments, but also well-crafted and elevated by Washington's singular blend of charisma, intelligence and tenacity.
Macy two-timing Stone with Graham? It really was a different time.

Offering gorgeous visuals along with fun songs and plenty of humor, Australian director George Miller's (Babe) Antarctica-set, computer-animated musical ranks just behind Cars among the year's animated films.
With Craig in the role, a Bond film suddenly seems like something to be taken seriously.

Carnahan, after glorifying violence and amorality throughout much of the film, tries to insert a heart and soul at the 11th hour. This means that a picture already too redolent of Quentin Tarantino and Guy Ritchie can't find its own tone.
The Brave One celebrates its avenging angel as it pretends to examine her.
Catch and Release is overlong and unfocused but not entirely unlikable. Unfortunately, its least likable element is its lead character, Gray, played by Jennifer Garner.
The film positively invigorates, largely because of O'Toole's Oscar-nominated performance, which is wise even when his character isn't.
Quality battles schlock throughout The Reaping. That is, until the picture's final act, when schlock swarms quality like ... oh, let's not spoil the surprise.
In most films, a bathroom-related joke would represent the lowest form of humor. In this one, it's a highlight.
Sweeping and intimate at once.
Offers impressive visuals, engaging action scenes and funny moments.
Equal parts inspiration, perspiration and hairspray, Blades of Glory is silly and enjoyable but not as consistently funny as Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby, Ferrell's last sports spoof.

Filmmaker Scott Frank develops characters and layers detail so well that his absorbing, well-acted crime thriller The Lookout sometimes doesn't seem like a crime thriller at all. It plays more as a study of a young man coping with life.
Without Wahlberg's rock-solid presence as a former Marine sniper turned hunted man, the mediocrity of Shooter would be clearer sooner.
Its worst feature, unfortunately, is the sports angle, which is mishandled by director Sunu Gonera and the film's four screenwriters.
Any extraneous elements seem to fall away as we gain greater insight into Charlie's devastation. At this point, it's not a matter of whether the viewer will cry, but how much.
The ultimate message of Mimzy seems to be: Help save the world, kids, but do it while enjoying the movie's preferred brand of lemon-lime soda.
[Zellwegger's and McGregor's] performances bring great joy to this picture, which is slight but satisfying, like a favorite children's book revisited as an adult.
Chris Rock's direction of I Think I Love My Wife isn't especially noteworthy. His screenwriting (with comedian Louis C.K.) is all over the map.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Premonition is a thriller with a major gimmick, a few moments of suspense and a profoundly unsatisfying ending. As such, it plays much like a C-grade cable thriller.
Growing less lurid and more poignant as it builds its story through a series of linked vignettes, this film by Karen Moncrieff provides a showcase for its predominantly female cast.
Once the Spartans start cracking jokes while finishing off opponents with spears, 300 starts to wobble.
A movie that takes on sex, religion and race in the rural South. But the most enduring aspect of this film, written and directed by Craig Brewer, is its great compassion.

A less-skillful director might, say, up the fog quotient for a film about murder and San Francisco. But you get the feeling that Fincher researched the old weather reports for every day depicted in the film.
Wild Hogs is lame enough throughout that you wonder why John Travolta, Martin Lawrence, Tim Allen and William H. Macy signed on for it.
Lovely on many levels, from its gauzily sunlit interiors and sweeping shots of stunning landscape to its warm depiction of family, The Astronaut Farmer reveals an ornery individualism as it unfolds.

People unfamiliar with the show might find the movie amusing. People unaware of the Keystone Kops might find it hilarious. But for fans of the series, the movie plays like a stretched-out version of one of the less-stellar episodes.
They're good collaborators, even if the song they're hammering out isn't very memorable.
Perhaps a release at this time is meant to capitalize on Murphy's artistic comeback. Instead, Norbit serves as a feature-length reminder of why he needed a comeback.
Even though Eastern Promises inhabits a creepy world, Cronenberg fans still might be reluctant to leave it.

Charlotte's Web gives E.B. White's classic tale a spiffy cinematic update but leaves its core values intact. Visually accomplished and heartfelt, this G-rated gem is radiant, terrific and really some film.
Set in postwar Bosnia, The Hunting Party is all over the place in tone and seeming intent.
Though, as a broad comedy concerned with Israeli-Palestinian relations, Zohan in some ways distinguishes itself as original, it ultimately plays as just another silly Sandler comedy.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A girl can never have too many outfits, but a film can have too many scenes.
Though we always know where things are going, the film still frightens from moment to moment.

Self-aware in the best possible way, Kingdom of the Crystal Skull cultivates a collective sense of nostalgia that carries it past mumbo-jumbo story developments and action scenes that could have used less CGI.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's all there: the whoosh and bash of close-contact racing, the raised-oval sliding, the loop-de-loops. All but the ability to discern what's going on.

Directed by Tom Vaughan and written by Dana Fox, who also wrote the excruciating The Wedding Date, this film often seems improvised, and not in a good way. Some setups go nowhere, and some jokes never get set up at all.
Director Paul Weiland and the film's screenwriters offer standard sitcom setups and forgettable supporting characters, in effect hanging the whole picture on Dempsey.
Action scenes in comic-book films? Overrated. That's the lesson of Iron Man, which goes light on CGI fireworks but heavy enough on its most electrifying element -- Robert Downey Jr. -- to compensate.
High in gloss and light on brains.
This story of a corporate vice president and the surrogate mother she hires is so committed to convention that it runs into cliché.
Assigning Chan and Li to supporting status underscores how ordinary this would-be- extraordinary film turns out to be.
Forgetting Sarah Marshall is a heartwarming romantic comedy in which boy loses girl, meets new girl and eventually finds himself.
An amiable dramedy that never quite kicks into gear.
A B-level cop thriller with an A-list cast, Street Kings engages when taken on its own, trashy terms. But even at that, the film provokes unintentional laughter.

Scorsese, who has used Stones songs so prominently in his movies that he's probably paid for a few outbuildings on the band members' country estates, brings an obvious fondness for the group to Shine a Light.

Directed by Jennifer Flackett and Mark Levin, and adapted from a novel by Wendy Orr, Nim's Island offers a nice message for kids and grown-ups: Be the hero of your own story, whether confronting a volcano or 'borderline agoraphobia.'
When a film stars three people you adore and still falters, the instinct is to blame the director. But that's tricky when the director is one of the people you adore.
Carolla is winning in The Hammer, which evokes Rocky and just about every other lovable-loser sports movie while showing enough comic originality to hold interest throughout.
Like Wilson, Mann can wring laughs even from mediocre lines. Here's an idea: How about Apatow and Rogen forget the freaky-geeky boys for a while and give Mann a starring role?

Though its smaller story of a mother and son will elicit tears, Under the Same Moon is clear-eyed in its larger examination of the cycle of poverty that persists for immigrants on this side of the border.
Reynolds lets us see the wheels turn throughout this process, crafting Frank's stark behavior change as the thinking man's flip-out.

Resistance is not just futile but almost seems churlish in the black-and-white face of such cuteness. Along with some terrific voice performances and lovely animation, the adorability quotient of Kung Fu Panda buoys the film.

At times, the action in Horton overwhelms its softer, more Seussian traits. At these moments, the picture comes across as just another computer-animated film -- and there must be 100 by now -- about an animal on a quest.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The story essentially stops moving midway through. All that's going to occur, in terms of building any true dramatic tension, already has happened by this point.
A washout plot places the emphasis, by default, on the film's uneven action sequences and the faulty chemistry between Carell and Anne Hathaway.

In the Valley of Elah offers a fine example of a mutually beneficial pairing of filmmaker and actor. Director and co-screenwriter Paul Haggis gives Tommy Lee Jones a great role. In exchange, Jones supplies Haggis with nuance.

The momentum increases considerably in the final hour of this 2-hour, 40-minute film, when Lee combines action and emotion in a way that makes cinematic sense. But it's a long, spotty time getting there.
Even though their clinches aren't sexy, Gere and Lane still make an extremely attractive pair. They seem to fit together, whether dancing or just talking.
Leoni seems genuinely delighted by Gervais, cracking up with a gusto that never seems rehearsed.
A would-be thriller lacking in suspense, Lakeview Terrace nonetheless commands attention throughout.
An entertaining but slight Coen brothers comedy that benefits immensely from Pitt's and Clooney's dumbbell acts.
Coogan brings an innocent quality to Dana, who knows he lacks talent but loves the craft so much that he hangs on however he can.
[An] engaging, well-acted French thriller based on a novel by American writer Harlan Coben.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Bottle Shock takes a fascinating historic event... and renders it as a sidelight to an overindulged father-son conflict and story lines that start out well but never go anywhere.
Never much of a scene-stealer before now, the delightful Franco runs away with Pineapple Express.
The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor is a cheeseball film that's hard to love but impossible to hate.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sometimes, an actor's enthusiasm for a role can carry a performance past its more awkward moments.
What's most surprising is the filmmakers' treatment of two key characters. Linked by the story to a hot-button topic, these characters are presented in a most unenlightened fashion.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though Ferrell and Reilly bring puppyish enthusiasm to scenes in which the overgrown boys bond, the shift to friendship leaves Step Brothers with nowhere to go.
Quite good. Nolan's visually sophisticated and well-acted sequel engages and even wows for about two hours of its 2 1/2 -hour run time.
Combining animatronics, digital effects -- and most important, the director's fertile imagination -- Hellboy II gives us a taste of the magic del Toro is sure to bring to J.R.R. Tolkien's The Hobbit.
Kit Kittredge: An American Girl will please girls who appreciate determined young heroines and lessons in U.S. social and economic history.
Ill-conceived and oddly executed, this Will Smith vehicle perplexes more often than it entertains.
Offers a touching robot romance, visuals as artful as they are state-of-the- art, and vital messages about environmental and personal health.
Wanted engages and even wows throughout, thanks to its exceptional visuals and something far more rare in a summer blockbuster: a stellar lead performance.
The worse the joke is, the greater the manic gleam in Myers' eyes. He's trying to sell setups he probably knows aren't funny, and the strain can be hard to watch.
There are just too many "almosts" attached to this Hulk.
The film's deliberate pace combines with an overall bleakness to alienate the viewer.
A moving character study and romance based on the novel The Dying Animal by Philip Roth.
Most of us know where this story is headed (ba-da-bum), and in order for the moment in question to have impact (ba-da-thump), Anne should engender at least a modicum of sympathy.

Sidney Lumet's Before the Devil Knows You're Dead starts with a bad idea -- a plan by two brothers to rob their parents' jewelry store -- and whips itself into a beautifully acted, nervous-making frenzy of a melodrama.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Plays more like an adaptation of Wilt Chamberlain's autobiography than of Garca Mrquez's novel.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The special effects are too obvious at times, and in trying to impart an eccentric vibe, Helm relies too heavily on kooky camera angles.
Director Robert Zemeckis and his technical wizards have turned an English-class staple into a ripping -- not to mention ripped -- comic-book yarn that looks spectacular in Imax 3-D.
Lions for Lambs is insightful and provocative.

Some humor in Bee Movie is too sophisticated for little kids, but there are enough dazzling action scenes to compensate. Youngsters won't get an allusion to The Graduate, but they'll enjoy the slapstick that follows.
American Gangster is 2 1/2 hours of pleasure with a guilty aftertaste.
The film moves from dark to dispiriting and back to dark.
Hedges imparts, in the space of an hour and a half, a real sense of this family's history -- its rituals and its resilience.
Filmmakers Joel and Ethan Coen build and sustain tension so masterfully throughout this adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's novel that even trouble that's been telegraphed still shocks when it arrives.
Watching Del Toro bring glimmers of intelligence and kindness to his character's messed-up surface makes the audience want to stick with him through the movie.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though light on revelations, this well-acted film offers entertaining and touching moments.
The sex scenes are the most memorable parts of the NC-17 rated Lust, Caution, and not just because they are explicit. They break through the reserve of this stylish but emotionally removed picture.

On an entertainment level, this film is a surefire treat for the armchair paleontologist and child alike. It also has the look and feel of a project that was meticulously researched, as befits most National Geographic projects.

Director-screenwriter Sean Penn's gorgeous, compassionate film takes a generous approach to the story of McCandless, the real-life seeker who gave away his savings and belongings and walked into the Alaskan wilderness.
Director Robin Swicord introduces just enough hustle and bustle to demonstrate that the romantic joys and negotiations found in Austen's plots can survive in any era or setting.
The makers of this family film dumb down some material so much that it fails to tickle funny bones of any age.
A story line involving a crusty fisherman and a giant, fabled fish plays as unintentionally comic. Other moments are visually excessive.
So much of Youth Without Youth is impenetrable, and not in a way that makes you want to solve the puzzle, but in a way that makes you want to knock the puzzle pieces off the table and flee the room.
With her performance in Interview, Sienna Miller does more for today's tabloid-fixture starlets than they'll ever do for themselves.
[An] accomplished directorial debut.

King is too strong a presence to be convincing as a pushover. She's still interesting to watch, and her character's friction with sister Kelli seem truthful at moments. But just about everything involving Lisa and her husband is a stretch.
Handheld camera work and jumpy editing render The Kingdom unsteady throughout. But the film doesn't topple until it visually evokes the Daniel Pearl case.
Will Smith passes a big test -- let's call it the Tom Hanks-in-Cast Away test -- for any movie star: carrying a movie alone for most of the way.
Jumper takes leaps that have nothing to do with telepathic transporting. They involve logic and storytelling, and they doom this sci-fi film.

t's a perfectly agreeable way to while away an hour and a half -- but don't expect to remember much about it in the morning.

An essential component of what is now destined to be among the best film franchises of all time.

One of the cleverest comedies to happen along in ages.

No christmas day would be complete without spending the afternoon falling asleep in front of this film.

Flimsy but fun, this rom-com has an enjoyable edge to it -- just don't expect to remember much about it in the morning.
It's charming enough, though, and there's plenty of laughs.
If you sit back, relax and just accept it for what it is -- an enjoyable, escapist Gothic pantomime -- you will go home happy.

movie_review_blurb: It's a perfectly respectable debut for Curtis.

Ultimately, this is just a big, dumb, commercial suspenser - but it's one of the best for ages, reminding us that it is still possible to make a high quality piece of popcorn entertainment.
Just perfect.
Endlessly quotable, strangely fascinating and immensely charming.

A big-hearted light-headed story that isn't as deep as it wants to be, but still manages to entertain.

A slick comedy that's more fun than it has any right to be.

Raunchily entertaining.
Ruben's film is more like The Sixth Nonsense.
A series of Hallmark-card platitudes, not a human portrait.
Zarhin's episodic, unpredictable film is life-affirming.

Mr. 3000 is not a great movie, but it's affectionate. It reveals the cuddly side of Mac. It reimagines midlife romance with the warmth of a Spencer Tracy-Katharine Hepburn movie, if without its wit.

Garden State, Zach Braff's lyrical directorial debut, self-consciously announces itself as a baby buster generational marker -- and richly deserves the designation.
A laugh-out-loud if not-exactly-good stoner comedy.

movie_review_blurb: At its best this is a CQ (as in chuckle quietly) comedy rather than an LOL (as in laugh out loud) affair.
Our 8-year-old adored it. But except for Murray's voice-over work, Mom was allergic.
Not even Chan's imaginative fight choreography redeems this folly.
An entrancing story of how the neglected reconnect with the mother culture.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Moore's most accomplished, most devastating and most flawed film to date.
When the audience roared at Napoleon's almost spastic way of slicing the air with his limp-spaghetti arms, I cringed.
If it were a sandwich, it would be two slices of bread without filling. If it were a bridge, it would be two anchorages without a suspension in between. Nice anchorages, though.
Two Brothers may not be a great movie, but it's an unusually diverting episode of Wild Kingdom.
A deeply satisfying and involving sequel.
Like a Porter song, De-Lovely has melancholy, wit and style to burn.
Not much fun even for this fan of Alexa Vega from Spy Kids.
A mostly charmless affair.

Has the quiet urgency of a story that must be told.
Shyamalan deftly turns a familiar fairy tale into an eerie scary tale.

Searing and hypnotic.

I was shaken, but not stirred.

OK, so it's not a great movie. But like its hero, it has a great heart.
The film is emotionally affecting without being particularly distinguished.

Despite the appeal of cobra-eyed Thornton and bunny-nosed Heder, Scoundrels trips early, and often.
This sophomoric mix of the supernatural and screwball from Ivan Reitman is diverting, cheesy fun, with Thurman's G-Girl as a droll combination of Superwoman and Uber Shrew.
A documentary as efficient and zippy as its subject.

To the extent that Little Miss Sunshine works, and you probably gather that its schematic cartoonishness didn't always work for me, it is because directors Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris genuinely like these people.
A provocative but oddly unsatisfying film experiment.
[A] humanist movie of enormous empathy.

movie_review_blurb: Great message, so-so movie.

movie_review_blurb: I loved Science, but in its final minutes I felt that I had a one-way ticket to a cul-de-sac. The scenery is something, though.
Bill Condon's screen adaptation of the 1981 Broadway sensation is, if possible, as dazzling and energizing as its source.

Two words of advice: N'Ever mind.

movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

Evocatively shot with the saturated color of '60s film and accompanied by David Holmes' retro-mod score, Ocean's Thirteen is a boy's-night-out lark that girls can enjoy.

movie_review_blurb: Silva expertly maintains the tension, asking the audience to interpret Raquel's bizarro behavior. His diagnosis is a pleasant surprise.
I found myself reaching for a phantom video-game controller to help Our Heroes and Heroine defy certain death.
This swoony adaptation of the second installment in Stephenie Meyer's young-adult series is a potent stew of fairy tale and romance-novel fantasy.
Predictable as the premise is, Travolta's and Williams' unpredictability makes for some chortle-worthy slapstick, less of Laurel & Hardy vintage than of Abbott & Costello swill.
A one-of-a-kind experience that boasts a twice-in-a-lifetime performance from Nicolas Cage.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Brind's screenplay is pregnant with fascinating questions of identity and social anxiety. And Salky knows how to create a mood.

I don't know if it's the best movie of the year, but it's the most utterly enjoyable.
It may look like a movie-of-the-week and it certainly has some wincingly bad musical passages, but Invictus is an entertaining movie about a masterful piece of political theater.
With eye-popping saturated color and streamlined figures, codirectors Ron Clements and John Musker (the duo behind the vibrant Aladdin) lovingly invoke Harlem Renaissance artistry.
More strident than funny, the film illustrates that old French proverb, "Marriage is like a cage; one sees the birds outside desperate to get in, and those inside desperate to get out."
Did you hear about Did You Hear About the Morgans? Really, you don't want to.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Eric Bricker's glowing portrait of Shulman uses its subject's photos to persuade the viewer that one picture is worth a thousand architectural masterworks.
movie_title: Visual Acoustics: The Modernism of Julius Shulman (2009)

movie_review_blurb: I enjoyed the spectacle of middle-aged people making spectacles of themselves. And I appreciated the film's gentle understanding of how the romance of a parent affects the children.

A diverting showcase for Baruchel and Eve, who are excellent arguments for the proposition that there's more to a person than looks.
Diary of a Wimpy Kid, based on the popular illustrated tween books by Jeff Kinney, deserves a B- for effort and a C for execution.
There's something awfully literal about watching the group famous for the refrain "Neon angels on the road to ruin!" as just that. And not much more.
As talking-dog movies go, Marmaduke makes Beverly Hills Chihuahua look like Up.
Splices together the mad-scientist story with a satire of modern marriage and parenting. While the results are mad, brazenly unethical, and occasionally funny, the implications are deeply upsetting.
An appealing reboot of the 1984 inspirational that rethinks the American tale for the global age.
Michael Douglas is at his best when playing a character at his worst.
Spiced with melancholy and magic, Micmacs is an imaginative live-action film with the playfulness of an animation like Ratatouille.

movie_review_blurb: It is not to everyone's taste. But if you like the lush film operas of Rainer Werner Fassbinder, Douglas Sirk, or Luchino Visconti, this one's for you.

At times Let It Rain recalls one of those Katharine Hepburn comedies where the New Woman gets cut down to size so as not to intimidate the Old-School Men. Yet the film so likably deflates the pompous and pumps up the humble that it's hard not to like.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: At first it isn't clear whether the film that unfolds is a thriller, romance, or mystery. As it happens, it is all of the above.
Short, sweet-and-sour, and amusing rather than funny, Despicable Me can't help but be likable.
More Cheez Whiz than wizardly.
A glittery string of backstage conventions. Backstabbing! Pushy parents! Precocious stars! Blind ambition! But if you're a tween (and don't watch Glee), the cliches will be new to you.

The film succeeds as a music-industry satire, a very naughty version of Almost Famous.

Loved the slapstick, winced at the toilet humor, and mourned that the female performers were given so little to do.

This initiates a role reversal in which documentarian becomes artist and vice versa.

The fine actors show how we bond to those not related to us by blood -- and also how we love. Bring Kleenex.
It's larky, snarky fun.

movie_review_blurb: Kilcher is lovely. But sadly, Ka'iulani is a perfunctory biopic of the sort one might encounter on television during Women's History Month.

Look before you Leap Year.
Embrace the mystery, the Coens tell us. At the same time, they can't resist pulling the rug out from under our feet.

As a romcom, it's average, but as a Matthew McConaughey romcom, it's above average. If you're a low-expectations moviegoer, this one might surprise you.

A movie like Everlasting Moments comes along maybe once in a decade.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

Egoyan's most affecting film since The Sweet Hereafter.

It broods along as if it's expressing something monumentally important with each slow-as-molasses camera move.
The film finds the actors' performance deficiencies functioning less as signs of authentic teenage behavior than as an incompetent carrier of plot.
A phony collection of storytelling clichés held under the banner of archetype and lent a modicum of weight by the splendor of the landscape.

Familiar as its art/life paralleling may be, it's all fueled by a filmmaker with an intimate relationship to his subject matter.
This is exactly the kind of movie at which David Wain took aim with his sublime rom-com parody They Came Together.

A buoyant tribute, even if the pedigree of the project implies something more paradigm-shifting.

movie_title: La creazione di significato (The Creation of Meaning) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What comes through clearly by the end of the film is the act of one artist's eccentric generosity breathing new awareness into the life of another.
Writer-director Louise Archambault's neatly affirmative denouement is at odds with the more uncertain reality occurring at the edges of the film's drama.
Never once does it project an intuitive understanding of how humans would behave or react in the midst of such a shattering misfortune.
The lasting impact is of a restless soul whose showbiz drive is genuine.

From its first draw of blood onward, it bolts down a foreseeable slasher-movie trajectory, laying on thick the dramatic irony while constantly inventing new reasons to punish its characters for old iniquities.
The offhand jabs at the dissolution of orthodox craftsmanship in 1970s cinema are overwhelmed by a deeper core of autocritique played out in the film's downward trajectory.

Eugène Green's mannered direction doesn't work for every situation it's homogenously applied to, but at its most effective it inspires an enhanced sensitivity to the import of every gesture, visual or verbal.
The complicated psychological realities of army personnel require a tougher directorial treatment than the maudlin melodrama presented here.
The film isn't really fooling anyone into feeling doom-laden suspense (Paris, after all, is still standing), but the principal performers sell the momentousness of the drama.
It showcases a genuine fascination with the mind/body split engendered by Skyping, online dating, and constant app usage through a plot that doesn't fuel itself on received wisdom.
Of greatest damage to the doc's coherence is its wholehearted belief that its subjects are offering firsthand reports worth hearing.
The cinematographic approach of the film suggests some unholy hybrid of the aesthetic and genre indulgences of Michael Bay and the hyper-literalist plot construction of Christopher Nolan.
The narrative works through the many contradictions brewing inside its main character in the wake of his personal actualization without ever feeling like a dramatic checklist.
Its greatest asset, and another trait it shares with Mann and Fincher's work, is a careful attention toward the particulars of its milieu in a way that doesn't call attention to those period touches.
There's literally no way to miss the memo that It's All So Quiet is about dealing with the encroachment of death, as it's there in every scene.

Any masochistic joy that can be derived from watching the film owes to seeing it take its bullheaded conceit to its logical, artless extreme.

Ethan Hawke's concentration on Seymour Bernstein isn't a betrayal of his own ego massaging, but rather an attempt to have a genuine soul-bearing conversation.

Its bid for social correctness does nothing to make the juvenile and numbing fixation on brutality any more palatable.

Catalan prankster Albert Serra's film ultimately emerges as a compact, improbably riveting viewing experience.

movie_title: Portrait of a Garden (Portret van een tuin) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Even more diverse than the film's historical material is its eccentric mash-up of styles and approaches.
Yet Gravity also has an emotional and spiritual depth that, like 127 Hours, another film about man versus isolation, transcends what might at first seem a gimmicky plot device.

Though the romantic triangle provides the story's heart, it's the film's take on media as social control (Stanley Tucci returns as the unctuous TV host), sharp sense of action, and smart peformances that give Catching Fire its soul.
The simplistic Dallas Buyers Club is worth seeing, if for no other reason than McConaughey's transformative and touching performance.
But the much talked-about 12 Years a Slave is more than a beautifully shot art piece. It's history made violently real.
Those sounds you hear are the sighs of relief from Ben Affleck and Justin Timberlake. Runner Runner is no longer 2013's worst thriller.

Do Affleck and Timberlake, who together should have enough cash to make Midas jealous, need a payday this badly? That's the only real mystery at the heart of Runner Runner, a dull, slow-jog of a thriller that's less whodunit than why bother.
Lackluster, slow and with only hints of the combo of kineticism, kung fu and comedy that was part of Chan's appeal in the first place, Chinese Zodiacdoesn't do justice to the actor's filmic heritage.

With Captain Phillips, Greengrass doesn't disappoint, injecting the story with a sense of nervous energy and creeping claustrophobia. The movie manages to be both tense and suspenseful, even though the world knows how it ends.
The film is deserving of its position as a pioneer. It's a heartfelt, touching peek into the day-to-day life of a culture Westerners rarely get to see.
While there are no new explosive revelations in The Armstrong Lie - and, at just over two hours, it's a touch too long - it's still a mesmerizing cautionary tale.

The Fifth Estate is also as current as a news feed, filling in the disputed facts about Assange's life beyond the headlines and chronicling the revolution that has upended the media landscape in the last decade.

Jason Statham and James Franco squaring off over meth with a script by Sylvester Stallone? Sounds like a guilty pleasure, right? Unfortunately, the result is a rather rote action thriller that only comes alive during the well-staged fight scenes.
That Awkward Moment is pleasant enough, and it has some inspired moments, but they don't add up to anything that pushes the boundaries of the genre.
It has everything a viewer would expect when Hollywood goes blue-collar...But Furnace is saved by a couple of surprises and mostly by the performances from its big-ticket cast.
Night Train to Lisbon is a handsomely crafted, well-acted love story within a love story, even if it doesn't engage as much as it should.

So it's a relief and a pleasant surprise that Wall Street, despite some missteps and the need for an editor, mostly manages to live up to the interest generated by its kinetic trailers and the heavy hand of hype.

Elba may not look...like the South African leader, but his sheer presence makes you believe he is channeling him. Still, [it] falls frustratingly short as a cinematic experience, trying to cram too much of Mandela's colorful life into too little time.

For much of its first half, during which visuals replace vision, Walter Mitty stumbles down a rabbit hole of technological triumph. But then something unexpected happens: It turns into a sweetly engaging blockbuster.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A lonely young man falls head over keyboard in love with his computer's operating system...It's not just any operating system, but one designed to be empathetic with humans, and has Scarlett Johansson as its Siri-with-sex-appeal voice. Who could resist?
While not as powerful as [A Separation] ,The Past nevertheless is a fascinating, slow-burn depiction of a relationship in crisis.

Gooding gives a strong performance, but viewers might be better off seeking out the...documentary Brooklyn Castle, which focuses on the championship chess team at an inner-city New York middle school.
Hudgens captures both the defiance and fear of a girl at this crossroads. Her performance elevates what's often a trite and heavy-handed script.

The Monuments Men - with its shifting tone between light comedy and drama - rarely gets the viewer invested enough to really care what happens to them. And that's unfortunate, because it really is a fascinating footnote in history.
The Attorney features a powerful, energetic performance by Woo-Seok.
Gordon-Levitt enlivens Don Jon with such a sense of swagger, as a director, writer and actor, that the film feels fresh.

It doesn't matter that not all of the songs are memorable or that the performances are of varying success, the warm-hearted Black Nativity feels tailor-made to fit with the good tidings of the season.
The Trials of Muhammad Ali, Bill Siegel's fascinating documentary about the legendary boxer, cares less about how he handled himself in the ring than how he handled himself in life.

The Internship doesn't break any new comedic ground...But it's an amiable, occasionally laugh-out-loud fish-out-of-water tale that gently mocks our modern technological age while simultaneously embracing it.
Grim, gray and surprisingly gruesome, Prisoners - the director's first foray into English-language filmmaking - has its flaws, but predictability is not one of them.
But there's just something so relentlessly likable about put-upon, impoverished Frances (Greta Gerwig) that it almost doesn't matter that her New York is just one big Williamsburg.

What do you give the kid who has everything? His own summer action-adventure blockbuster, of course ... Well, it certainly beats a cake and a card, but considering what a well-crafted bore After Earth turns out to be, perhaps not by much.

The film's big reveal may not come as that much of a surprise; you may figure out where it's going well before the end. But it's the getting there that is, if not exactly fun, then certainly hypnotic.

The Kings of Summer is the cinematic equivalent of an Arctic-cold popsicle on a Sahara-hot day. Refreshing and satisfying but not overly sentimental, the film taps into the frustrations of adolescence with warmth and wit.
How (Jesse and Celine) try to rekindle that flame is what drives Midnight, a film that feels so authentic it's like overhearing a conversation you're not sure you should be hearing.
The Outsider doesn't break the action movie mold in any way but it is an efficient little, low-budget crime thriller that has the good sense to not overstay its welcome.
[It]gets derailed by [Rogen and Goldberg's] desire to keep upping the level of comedic absurdity and cheesy special effects. Still, there are lots of low-brow laughs, especially in the first half.

By the end, Man of Steel has mutated into just another superhero action movie, with explosions galore and city buildings toppling like so many Legos. Lather, rinse, repeat. That's too bad because ... Man of Steel has so much going for it.

A fun, if not particularly emotionally engaging, thrill ride ... Unlike the best in the zombie genre, the movie doesn't tap deep into the existential dread of succumbing to mob bloodlust and the fear of the crowd.
In Emmerich's universe, no one ever went broke underestimating the world's desire to see things go boom.

Shot mostly across scenic landscapes in New Mexico, Colorado and Utah, including Monument Valley, [it acts] as a visual tribute to some of the great Westerns of history shot by the likes of John Ford. This Lone Ranger won't be joining their ranks.

The Israeli-Arab conflict is stripped to its most intensely personal level in The Attack, a haunting and heartbreaking meditation on violence, choice, love and duty that is one of the most remarkable films of the year.
Sam Rockwell is one of Hollywood's most underrated actors and he shows why that's the case again in A Single Shot, a rural, neo-noir thriller that slowly pulls the viewer under its veil of mystery.
A Band Called Death shines the light on a previously unexplored corner of musical history and does it in an accessible, straightforward manner.
The problem with the film, directed by France's Rachid Bouchareb from a script by Joelle Touma and Marion Doussot, is that the men are mostly one-dimensional louts.
The fights are well-staged and there's just enough interstitial humanity among boxing matches to keep things from getting monotonous.
Even though we know where this dark road travels, the remarkable Fruitvale Station still manages to be both sorrowful and suspenseful while also celebrating a life only half-lived.
In a summer when so many of the hype-heavy movies turned out to be big-budget bores, it's refreshing when a movie like 2 Guns achieves its admittedly modest ambitions.

Directors Joshua Oppenheimer and Christine Cynn have created something extraordinary in The Act of Killing, the much-talked-about documentary about torture and murder during the Indonesian dictatorship of the '60s and '70s.
Director/writer [Neill] Blomkamp has tossed adie any sense of subtlety for a heavy-handed reprise of some of District 9's  basic themes hog-tied to a riff on undocumented immigration.
[Dierctor Jorge] Hinojosa does a good job of showing Iceberg's humanity without glossing over the viciousness of his chosen profession.
movie_title: Iceberg Slim: Portrait Of A Pimp (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's actually a well-made, well-acted low-budget thriller that is more resonant than expected.
It ranks with Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, Hero and House of Flying Daggers as one of the most elegant and beautiful martial-arts films to play American screens.
The lack of imagination in Riddick, the third installment in director/writer David Twohy's increasingly forgettable sci-fi franchise, is so stunning that it's almost like a special effect in itself.

From the swelling melody on the soundtrack that opens the film to the Wind Beneath My Wings-like ballad that closes it, Winnie Mandela ... feels less like history come alive than Hollywood hagiography at its most blandly sentimental.
An effectively epic and sometimes moving rendering of a momentous event that easily could have remained a historical footnote.
As with The Descendants, Faxon and Rash ably balance the humorous and the heavy, tipping neither toward the silly nor the mawkish.
It's unfortunate, then, that this RoboCop reboot shrugs off the pointed satire too soon, devolving into just another big action vehicle - even if it's a well-made, entertaining one at times.

There are many superhuman feats on display in the latest installment in the X-Men saga, Days of Future Past. Time travel. Saving the world from big, angry robots. A beautifully restored 1973 Buick Riviera.
Pompeii has as much to do with realism and history as the average gas station has with gourmet cuisine and fine dining. If you're hankering for something substantive, you'll leave hungry.

There's only one thing anyone really needs to know about [this] exercise in robot-on-robot violence: at nearly three hours, it's the longest "Transformers" yet. Any mention of the leaden dialogue [and] wooden acting...would just be piling on.

Though it may seem as if it's heading in the direction of being a feel-good movie Hellion doesn't go down that predictable road. It is more authentic than that, and that is indeed something to feel good about.

In different hands, Snowpiercer might have been just another generic action movie. Yet with South Korean director Bong Joon-ho at the helm, it's instead something more off-kilter and more disturbingly satisfying.

Yes, it's Hollywood at its most manipulative. Still, Heston would hate to hear this...but, at least from a moviegoer's perspective, the coming ape-ocracy may be nothing to fear and something to champion after all.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: At once a suspenseful mind game and a wily mash-up of surreal quantum physics theories, this low-cost thriller proves that something approaching brilliance is not just a function of budget.
So, while it's tempting to say that nothing happens in Boyhood, that would be wrong. What happens is everything.

The real sex tape that [the characters] Jay and Annie are chasing all over town might have at least had some instructive value. The movie Sex Tape that Jason and Cameron have made can't even make that claim.

This goofily enjoyable but ultimately forgettable techno-thriller plays like a cross between Transcendence and La Femme Nikita with a bit of Hong Kong-style action and low-rent 2001-era Stanley Kubrick thrown in for good measure.

Though not a great documentary and essentially a colorful, 3D commercial for Electric Daisy Carnival, it works as both an introduction to a subculture many may be unfamiliar with and as a beat-heavy scrapbook for those who were there.
As directed by James Gunn, Guardians of the Galaxy never takes itself seriously and it's often a visual and musical treat. The Runaways' Cherry Bomb and David Bowie's Moonage Daydream? Yes, please.
It's a moving, if occasionally heavy-handed, sports drama that deserves a wider audience than it is probably going to find in its limited release.
Taste, talent and lineage only go so far when nearly every line feels like it's from a script, not life. There's not a single surprise in this 96 minutes of millennial moaning.
A beautifully shot post-apocalyptic fever dream that might have worked as a short but is inconsequential as a feature film.
Sadly, the most expendable thing about The Expendables 3 is the movie itself.

It's the latest in the long line of movies made from novels set in a dystopian future where a young person has heroism thrust upon their slim shoulders...Yet, taken on its own, it's a well-made and effectively told morality tale.
Frank Miller and Robert Rodriguez's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For is like Paris after the zombie apocalypse: beautiful to look at but not a living soul in sight.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A clever amuse-bouche of a movie built around a conceit that can't be talked about in any detail...Let's just say it might have been something worthy of a Twilight Zone episode if Rod Serling were an indie filmmaker in the 21st century.
Kundo is not the best film of its type, but it's an entertaining amalgam.

Both Llewyn [Davis] and Frank may embody the spirit of the difficult musician, but Frank...is a more empathetic and engaging character, making Frank, the movie, a more bleakly funny yet ultimately touching film.
There's not much of a payoff, as this tepid film telegraphs its mild punches from several miles away.
With the arrival of The Drop, a disturbingly dark little thriller that wears its tension like a badge, the fall film season has arrived with a deadly bang.
While The Pirates has its moments -- as when Yeo-wol and Jang bond late in the film -- little of it is compelling as comedy, drama or action. About the only thing The Pirates steal is time.

Director Adam Wingard and writer Simon Barrett have fashioned a sly, entertaining tip of the hat to '70s-era John Carpenter films that also works on its own terms as crafty popcorn entertainment that never devolves into parody.
Take The Human Centipede and sprinkle liberally with the old Bob and Doug McKenzie sketches from SCTV and the result is Tusk, Kevin Smith's underbaked horror-comedy hybrid.

Just having Washington in the title role elevates the film from a tired rerun - complete with (yawn) brutal Russian mobsters - to a rousing, crowd-pleasing take on a movie formula, like a forgettable pop song turned into a dizzying jazz solo.

Good People grinds to its predictable, pat conclusion and betrays its generally solid performances and respectable artistic pedigree. Sometimes good people do bad things, sometimes they just make movies that start well and end badly.

A road-trip movie about a couple of guys nearing the end of life's road, Land Ho! is a sweetly simple tale that underscores what we already know but too often forget: Adventurism and finding your bliss are not just for the young.

While there are some effective moments early on - especially when Maddy confronts star player Terry (a suitably charming yet threatening Tom Williamson) - [the film] sinks under the weight of predictable plotting and cheap special effects.
Remember that feeling when you realized The Hangover II was A sequel that has as many laughs as a Texas spring has tornadoes.

It's refreshing to see teenage relationships handled with grace and depth...Director Josh Boone stays out of the way stylistically and lets the considerable naturalistic chemistry between Elgort and Woodley be the draw.

Non-Stop [is] an efficiently made exercise in airplane claustrophobia that takes off well enough but then crash-lands in the third act under the weight of its red herrings, improbability and plot twists.

The somber Omar isn't as controversial as Paradise Now but it too gets behind the TV news bulletins to discreetly put a human face on what is often just more electronic noise. Sometimes it's the quietest voices that are really the loudest.
Odd Thomas is an engagingly lightweight and occasionally visually inventive film that should appeal to Koontz fans and anyone else open to his whimsical approach to horror.
By the time the intricate plot and not particularly satisfying payoff are revealed at the film's end, many viewers will feel like they were the ones left holding the bag.
Artemisia may ultimately have lost the war in this clash of civilizations, but she wins our hearts.
Director David Ayer has made two of the best films about the tough lives of cops -- Training Day and End of Watch -- but his streak ends with the very violent and ultimately forgettable Sabotage.

Doremus' beautifully shot, naturalistic style means there are no soap-opera hysterics, and he gets strong performances from all involved...But it's hard to get over the fact that Jones, who was born in 1983, is far too old to play a high school student.
If Captain America: The Winter Soldier is indeed an augur of things to come during this special-effects-laden summer, maybe it won't be such a painful season after all.
Frankie & Alice feels like a film that might have been groundbreaking 40 years ago but has cable-TV movie of the week written all over it in 2014.
Carano, a former mixed-martial artist, won't be vying for an Oscar any time soon but she can more than hold her own as an action star. She deserves a bigger canvas on which to show off her skills.
Certainly, The Raid 2, a glorious head-butt of a movie, is not for the squeamish...but for those who prefer some slam in their cinema, it delivers.

In his first film as director, acclaimed cinematographer Wally Pfister (The Dark Knight Rises, Inception) has made a movie that predictably looks good but has little substance beneath its shiny, digitally enhanced surface.
Sometimes awkward and melodramatic, the debut film from director Mark Schmidt nevertheless derives strength from its little-known true-life story of Holocaust heroism.

Of course, the idea of setting a film around a person trapped in a confined space (Buried) or open space ( Gravity) can seem like a gimmick. But when it's done well, as it is here, it's something else: a cinematic joyride.
The performances are solid. Rogen does his usual, husky-boy geek thing while Efron seems more comfortable as a dreamboat than as a doctor in last year's Parkland. It's the script that lets them down.

There's the occasional false note. The proto-abolitionist Davinier has been given dialogue that verges on the preachy. But this is a small quibble in a story of 250-year-old pride and prejudice that resonates today.

The reboot perfectly illustrates the problem that has long haunted mediocre monster movies. When the big, scaly guys are on screen, it's a fun thrill ride. But when the humans are at the center of the action, things get scary - and not in a good way.
Chef is lightweight, and could be seen as just a blatant attempt to cash in on the whole food-truck phenomenon, but it's so engaging that it really doesn't matter.

As well made as it is, it would be great to see what McLean could do if he were free from genre conventions and could put his many talents to use in a movie not built around beheadings and dismemberments.
The moving documentary The Hornet's Nest is a boots-on-the-ground look at America's war in Afghanistan.
If Fast & Furious 6 were any dumber, the script would have been written in crayon ... [But] in terms of sheer action adrenaline, it may be the best film of the franchise.
It's sharply written, and moving without being mawkish, painting a portrait of people that we feel like we know.
While it shows Coppola has talent, it's also as aimless as her characters' self-absorbed, self-medicated, joyless lives.
A deliciously sweet confection of cinematic froth that lives up to its predecessors' sense of romantic fun.
A gritty, sweaty and entertaining little slice of Texas noir.

If there were a shootout in the Hollywood comedic corral between...Blazing Saddles, and the new kid in town, A Million Ways to Die in the West, it's not even a contest. Brooks' classic would chase the upstart out of town with a backside full of lead.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: To paraphrase an old dictum: Directors who don't learn from history - like their hapless heroes in sci-fi movies - are doomed to repeat it. But, in [Doug] Liman's case, that has turned out to be not such a bad thing.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Boccia (who also co-wrote with three others) displays a keen visual sensibility that, despite the film's low budget, gives it a palpable energy. It will be intriguing to see what he does next.
Star Trek Into Darkness is a step forward from Abrams' initial foray into this universe in the 2009 movie.
For sure, The Last Stand is no Terminator, but it is a fun, if predictable, action-thriller.

The perfectionist Luhrmann ... captures the exterior excesses of Gatsby's life but overlooks the interior torment that fuels them. Without the latter, Gatsby is less a film and more of a salute to production design.
Klapisch, who shoots Paris with the eye of someone rapturously in love with the town, is less interested in the reality than the romance.
Everyone seems as if they're going through the motions.
When it comes to genre filmmaking, Zombieland, a grisly comedy about yet another attack of the ravenous undead, does just about everything right.
As predictable and cliché as Free Style is, it moves along briskly enough and Bleu is compelling enough that it doesn't wear out its welcome.

It manages to veer from touching to humorous (Warr has some rather unconventional parenting techniques) without being overly mawkish, and the sumptuous cinematography by Greig Fraser is perhaps the best commercial ever for South Australia.
An amiable if easily forgotten story of middle-age romance set amid the sun-splashed Greek Islands.
Trucker is a knockout.
The Canyon is undermined by the expectation of a big payoff that never comes.
By the end, the incredulity stems not from the fact that this happened but that the wider world didn't know about it before now.
Ong Bak 2 is really just an excuse for several jaw-dropping set pieces that show off Jaa's killing skills.
It sports a gentle amiability that's engaging.

The film has won a theater full of awards overseas, including Outstanding British Film at the BAFTA Film Awards and the Jury Prize at Cannes. Fish Tank deserves to do equally as well on this side of the pond.
It's a fun premise -- a twist on the usual girl-in-distress scenario of the standard-issue horror film -- enlivened by Codyspeak.
Black Dynamite will stir some pleasant memories.
It's rambling, doesn't really go anywhere, and is not necessarily about anything beyond its own sense of place. But it's mildly diverting nonetheless. It's about mood, not plot.
Beautifully shot and well-acted, if earnest, overlong and unfocused.
An absorbing and contemplative detective story in which the high point of the action involves reading from a dictionary. Really.
Oceans is more of a random collection of images from the deep. But, boy, what images.
A winning and celebratory look at Tehran's distressed rock musicians.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Square announces the arrival of a new talent worth watching.
An engrossing, if flawed, techno thriller that never quite goes where expected, and that's what makes it such a pleasant surprise.
Some movies are just bad. Some are so bad they're good. And others are so intensely bad that they rise to a level of perverse greatness.
Directors Stéphane Aubier and Vincent Patar (who also provide voices) display a pleasantly warped sensibility without going for adult humor.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An effectively epic and sometimes moving rendering of a momentous event that easily could have remained a historical footnote.
Its elegiac mood and chiaroscuro beauty are hard to shake.
Freewheeling and funny.
The threesome's constant conversation amid the building unease helps establish them as characters with which the audience can identify.
A compelling glimpse of a community and, by extension, a country, in the throes of change.
Broken Hill, with its picture-postcard shots of the vast Outback, looks good and fills a niche for families.
This might go down as the year that science-fiction cinema, despite the deafening crash and clangor of sparring robots, began to rediscover its brains, heart and soul.

Director John Curran has a sense for visual grandeur. The landscape is ablaze with heat, dust, flies and a staggering loneliness. When a snake slithers across Davidson as she sleeps, you can almost feel its cold against the skin.
Quote not available.
The characters prove to be engaging and their quite real human emotions are enough to carry it.
movie_title: Le goût des autres (The Taste of Others) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, Croft loses to the most dangerous villain of them all: mediocrity.
A breezy pleasure.
Cradle boasts a couple of bravura fight and chase scenes but they're stranded amid the predictable and the pedestrian.
A good story, exceedingly well told.

Chandni Chowk isn't going to appeal to those not already entertained by Bollywood and kung-fu movie clichés. But it could turn the charismatic Kumar into a global star, making the prescribed happy ending even sweeter for Warner Bros.
An unexpectedly enjoyable science-fiction adventure that should be generating louder fanboy buzz than it has so far.
Quote not available.
Good intentions and huggable canines go only so far in the face of a predictable script and casting so random that everyone involved seems barely part of the same species, let alone the same family.
What inspired his faith in the first place? Does he have family? How did his constant wandering affect them?
movie_title: The Cross(The Cross: The Arthur Blessitt Story) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Be sure to stay through the closing credits as the scenes of Senegalese life act as a captivating coda to a film pulsing with music and memory.
movie_title: Youssou Ndour: I Bring What I Love (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While this seems like familiar territory, in the hands of director Jan Hrebejk and his longtime screenwriting partner, Petr Jarchovský, it's an engrossing, layered story of the ill-fitting choices and compromises everyone makes.
The biggest lesson from Spinning Into Butter has nothing to do with the ethics of race and more with realizing that every hit play doesn't need to be turned into a movie.

Directors Alastair Fothergill and Mark Linfield mostly avoid speaking directly of social issues. Instead, they let the visuals and the animals' plights underscore the importance of maintaining a healthy ecosystem.
Quote not available.
Solid performances combine with a sense of warm naturalism to make for engaging, memorable drama.
It'll be intriguing to see where Miranda goes from here.
Enlighten Up! is a low-key, charming trip.
Quote not available.

A winning and surprisingly moving documentary about -- wait for it -- a struggling Canadian heavy metal band that apparently influenced a generation of hard-rockers including Metallica, Anthrax and Guns N' Roses.
This sweetly engaging trifle goes down as easy as cold lemonade on a hot afternoon.
David Twohy doesn't do much new and the twist is as obvious as a tornado in the Texas Panhandle. But that doesn't make it any less of an escapist joyride on a hot summer day.
It has been a good year for animation that pushes thematic and visual boundaries.
The two of them look terrific together, too -- enough so that you wish someone would cast them together in a much better movie.
While there's a lot to admire, it all feels like an engaging though needless academic exercise.
Quote not available.
Despite a nice twist at the end and at least one deliciously demonic over-the-top performance, it's about as scary as The Simpsons "Treehouse of Horror" episode.
Cassel, who took the best actor award at France's equivalent of the Oscars for this role, is compulsively watchable.

A mashup of the spaghetti Western Django and '70s blaxploitation Westerns, it offers Tarantino another chance to show off his twist on history. While it worked with Inglourious Basterds, it just comes across as contrived and excessive here.
The movie threatens to become one of those late '60s/early '70s heavy-handed message movies, but it's somewhat salvaged by Damon's innate likability and the chemistry among the cast.
[It's]a harrowing adventure behind the headlines that is at once a riveting procedural and, at the same time, a bracing political statement on the moral ambiguities of our war on terror.
Perhaps Jaws and Open Water are the only other movie experiences that might engender more fear of the sea.
Gangster Squad may be loosely based on truth -- the takedown of notorious Los Angeles crime lord Mickey Cohen 60 years ago -- but it feels about as real as a mob-themed costume party.
While Broken City is hardly revolutionary, it's a slyly entertaining cop saga that leans more heavily on acting and dialogue than gunplay and chases.
Warm Bodies is a sweetly funny and touching riff on Beauty and the Beast or Romeo and Juliet -- if the Beast feasted on flesh or Romeo came back from the dead.
If this is indeed Soderbergh's final theatrical film, as the director has said he's going into semi-retirement, it's not such a bad way to go out.
Unlike Peter Jackson with the overstuffed The Hobbit,[director Bryan]Singer shies away from the epic and settles for entertaining. Sometimes that's more than enough.
Yet, like so many big-budget movies these days, it's hard to care much about what's going on, especially as the film builds to its special-effects-driven conclusion.

There are a lot of big stars...What's missing are a lot of big laughs. Well, there are about four...so that's quite a bit of downtime between guffaws to contemplate just why so many people who should know better are involved in this.
A mash-up of last year's teensploitation opus Project X, Pulp Fiction, Natural Born Killers and a Girls Gone Wild video.
The plotting, the planning and the deepening relationships don't make for kinetic action, but they are the foundation for a smart, engrossing film.
By the time the film finally gets to its conclusion -- an obvious set-up for a sequel -- you may wish you'd been possessed by aliens for the previous couple of hours.

The Sapphires shouldn't gleam as brightly as it does. The up-from-struggle story follows the predictable form of movies like these, from Dreamgirls to The Commitments. But there's such a sense of joy ... that it's hard not to be won over.
Tomorrow You're Gone looks like it was made after reading the first chapter of Noir for Dummies.

Even the most woefully sports-ignorant probably know all the plot points here by heart. For all its feel-good sports-movie predictability, 42 ... is surprisingly effective and even, at a couple of points, moving.

Built around several seemingly separate but ultimately interconnected stories, Disconnect will earn comparisons to Crash. Yet unlike Crash ... Disconnect tempers its more over-the-top moments with a real sense of tension and emotion.
At 2 1/2 hours, Fists of Legend goes on too long. But Kang Woo-suk's take on a genre often relegated to the level of cartoon is a refreshing change of pace.
Take (500) Days of Summer and Garden State, strip away their charms and you end up with Language of a Broken Heart, a handsomely shot but tired pile-up of indie rom-com clichés.

Stitched together from spare bits of other, often better films,[it]stumbles awkwardly in story and plot, shuffling toward the predictable explosions and fireballs of the third act. Yet...Oblivion is so beautiful to look at.
Taken as a whole, it's an impressive piece of filmmaking that shows Carruth's talents as director, actor, cinematographer and composer.

Mud has the feel of a novel ... that's rooted deep in American soil. Yet it was written specifically for the screen by [Jeff] Nichols, who has conjured up a coming-of-age story set in the South that doesn't resort to using caricatures and cliches.
But at heart, it's still a Michael Bay movie: loud as a Harley at midnight, empty as a dance club at noon, yet as beautiful to look at as a sunrise in Miami, where it's set.

Iron Man 3 manages to rise above its naked ambitions thanks to ... Robert Downey Jr.'s sly charm ... and Ben Kingsley's too-short and ... hilarious turn as the villainous Mandarin, a clever update on the comic-book character created in the '60s.
Kon-Tiki has the look and feel of a big, bracing adventure. It skirts many of the emotional issues in favor of high adventure with hungry sharks and monster storms.

[This] is an efficient, exceedingly grisly horror film that goes places that Raimi could only dream of in the '80s ... Yet, without the low-rent cheesiness ... that made the originals so enjoyable, [it] becomes a numbing exercise in overkill.
There are few laugh-out-loud scenes. Yet maybe that's the point. That life isn't about the grand gesture but the little day-to-day details that keep us grounded and human.

Any Day Now, about a gay couple in '70s LA trying to adopt a boy with Down syndrome, has movie-of-the-week melodrama written all over it. But it rises above the saccharin thanks to strong performances.

His first installment of The Hobbit, Tolkien's relatively slim precursor to the sprawling "Rings" saga, is a technically impressive but bloated adventure that makes you feel every one of its 169 minutes.
Far more entertaining, and infinitely less cumbersome, than its recent big-budget Hollywood counterparts.
[It] doesn't dig deeply into why Mesrine was the way he was. It's propelled by such a forceful performance from Cassel that, in the end, it hardly matters.

When Australian Aborigines appear on the big screen, it's rare to see them as fully fleshed-out contemporary human beings. That's where this lightweight and enjoyable, if frustratingly uneven, comedy-musical makes its biggest contribution.
It concerns an older man, alone during the holidays, who unexpectedly finds love. It also features two strong performances from veteran actors Martin Landau and Ellen Burstyn.
Monsters is far from perfect, but as a calling card for a rising young talent, it's impressive.
Despite the lack of surprises and a too-neat ending, Today's Special radiates charming warmth.
Welcome to the Rileys is a reminder that good, or at least intriguing, things can come in what seem to be predictable packages.
It just seems like a bunch of actors playing dress-up.
A thoughtful, if sometimes frustrating, tale of a Frenchwoman caught in the middle of a civil war in an unidentified African country.
Based on a novel by Dallas-based Matt Bondurant about his family's real-life bootlegging past, it's a violent, brooding portrait of brotherhood in trying times.
For followers of wuxia films, the epic Flying Swords of Dragon Gate  is a godsend...But the convoluted storyline...blunts the appeal for anyone who's not a fan.
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: If given the choice between going to class and seeing the high-school comedy General Education, go with school.
The Master may go down as one of Paul Thomas Anderson's most compelling works for two simple reasons: Joaquin Phoenix and Philip Seymour Hoffman.
There's the adage that life is nasty, brutish and short. It's even worse when you're half-naked and locked in a supply room with your boss.
Hellbound will probably find favor mostly with a Christian-film audience when, if [director Kevin Miller] had cast a wider net, it might have had broader appeal.
10 Years is no Big Chill, but it has just enough warmth to keep it alive.
The ingredients in [this] cop drama are as routine as a traffic stop. But director/writer David Ayer (who wrote the electric good-cop/bad-cop  Training Day) makes it work.

There hasn't been much lately for those who crave some brain power along with their effects-driven firepower. Now comes Looper, the time-travel tease from Rian Johnson that is an immensely fun yet thought-provoking ride.
Taken 2 ... has the requisite abductions, speeding cars and Americans in danger on foreign soil, but the only ones truly taken for a ride here are those of us in the audience.

This frontline skirmish in the culture wars [over school textbooks] is the subject of Scott Thurman's engrossing documentary ... It's a symbolic fight of our times, making [the film] a compelling and involving work.

With its blend of low-rent gangster cool, high-body-count hipster violence, smart-mouth dialogue, inspired casting and a blissfully retro soundtrack...[this]might have been a groundbreaking film -- in 1992.

The cross-cultural, steampunk, martial arts/comic-book Sino-Anglo mash-up...[is]visually entertaining. But...its considerable charms may prove exhausting before its relatively brief, 95-minute run time is over.
In an era when so much of the focus in sports is on the glam and the glitz, it's nice to be reminded that it can still be about heart and soul, too.
History may not always be fun, but, at least in this case, it's fascinating.
Technology and transcendence may sometimes be at war, but in Life of Pi, Ang Lee's spectacular take on the popular Yann Martel novel, they instead make for graceful dance partners.

The anvils of obviousness rain down so hard and fast in New Zealand-born/Australian-based director Andrew Dominik's meditation on low-rent crime and American decline, that it might as well be a Coyote-Road Runner cartoon
The movie isn't scary enough for horror fans, gruesome enough for the slasher crowd or campy enough to be funny, so it falls into something of a cinematic purgatory.

Set in a village in (Mexico), the slow, thoughtful and absorbing portrait of a working-class family whose father has just returned from being an undocumented worker in New York, Aquí y Allá puts a face ... on the immigration debate.
[Duvall and Downey] may not be enough to counterbalance the bloat of the rest of the film, but they keep it from sinking under the weight of soggy sentimentality.
It's amazing how the inquisitive eye can find one intriguing cultural thread, tug on it and then unravel a fascinating forgotten history.

Whiplash is, at best, heightened realism. There's no way that Fletcher could have gotten away with his teaching methods without serious legal - or physical - pushback long before Andrew comes along. But, as drama, it's a crackling good time.
A forceful indictment of the curdled masculinity that fuels some of the more extreme frat house behaviors that have made the news.
A gorgeously shot, tear-stained love letter to female friendship that also provides a fascinating look into contemporary, urban China.

As an effects-driven disaster movie starring two totems of testosterone - Mark Wahlberg and Kurt Russell - and directed by Peter Berg ( Lone Survivor, Friday Night Lights), Deepwater Horizon is alarmingly effective.
The film isn't the unqualified stroke of brilliance its Sundance honors might indicate, nor is it the overblown failure its detractors might desire.

But, even at its most obvious and ham-fisted, American Honey remains compelling, largely for Arnold's vividly verité, documentary-like cinematic style and a career-launching performance by Texan Sasha Lane who has never acted in a film before this.
It turns into a predictable cat-and-mouse game with one standout performance by the killer's enthusiastically ride-or-die German Shepherd.

At once a throwback to so many of the off-kilter Australian films of the '70s and '80s and a declaration of a promising new voice, Girl Asleep doesn't always hold together...But that's all part of the film's adventurous appeal.
In a Valley of Violence juggles Western tropes with the skill of Wyatt Earp in a gunfight.
It brings the terror of those 90 minutes on a sizzling 100-degree August day to vivid life.
The film soon moves from the familiar to the foreign, becoming a textured exploration of black masculinity and coming-of-age that plumbs beyond clichés and stereotypes.
Despite the confrontational nature of the subject matter, Loving is not a loud movie. It's a dramatic whisper instead of a shout.

Arrival is at its best when pregnant with the suspense of the possible, when the unidentified stationary objects bear no trace of their intentions. But the film becomes less intriguing as the story's direction moves from teasingly opaque to crystal-clear.
As with The Equalizer, Washington's commanding presence helps elevate what otherwise might be ordinary.

Dog Eat Dog is at its best when it's both strangely fascinating and repellant...But, like a fat tire with a nail, it loses air as it goes along and you're just left hoping that Cage and Dafoe bought themselves something nice with their paychecks.
Allied won't make anyone forget Casablanca, but it won't make them wish they'd stayed home and watched it instead either.
To his credit, a beefed-up LaBeouf throws himself into the role with fervor, and Clint Mansell's score bears a haunting beauty. But none of it is enough to save Man Down.
[Three Days in August] doesn't really go anywhere unexpected. But the journey remains involving.
This is the kind of debut that whets the appetite for what else this filmmaker has up his sleeve.
A rather cartoonish and not particularly credible political thriller from director John Madden, it doesn't live up to the ferocious promise of its lead character.
If you're not a fan, Rogue One may not be the revelation that The Force Awakens turned out to be. But it won't have you wishing for your own personal Death Star either.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Larrain's gorgeously grim and austere vision bolsters a bravura performance from Natalie Portman. She inhabits Jackie as a woman who has been shaken to her core with grief.

While the film is neither novel nor revolutionary, it's the kind of cinematic warm blanket that feels very comforting and satisfying right now...That it's a true story...makes it all the more affecting.

It's not a complete waste of time as there are a few magical Chan moments as when he's fighting off and dodging bad guys on the top of a speeding train...Chan, at 62, may not be as nimble as he once was but what he can do is still very impressive.

Patriots Day lands with all the subtlety of one of the deadly explosions that claimed three lives and injured 264 others. Terrorism, bad. Law enforcement, first responders, marathon runners and onlookers, good...But, boy, it's effective.

Without Michael Keaton's fascinating and slyly ferocious performance as Kroc at its heart, The Founder might still be a biting critique of Kroc in particular and rapacious corporate capitalism in general but it wouldn't be nearly as delicious.
The film feels like an extended episode of The Wonder Years, if that '60s-set series had served a little chicken tikka masala and cross-cultural understanding with its white bread and pop hits.
