Paul is an irresistible creature thanks to Rogen's deadpan delivery. This pleasant film is more clever than funny, referring to old alien films instead of joking about them.
A rare film, one that is intelligent, emotional and exciting.
The film has a genial it's-only-a-movie attitude that sets it apart, quite emphatically, from other blockbuster action movies.
One of the most spectacular entertainments in years.
An amusing, breezily apolitical documentary about life on the campaign trail.

Turns out to be an inane fish-out-of-water comedy. Along the way it turns into a virtual McDonald's commercial, too. The fact that you can hardly tell the difference is a good clue to the movie's bad-television flavor.
Just don't expect their bickering to be on the level of Neil Simon, and you won't be disappointed.
Casper's movie is not the cleverest one around, but its hero may be the most lovable.
Choose the part that suits your taste, but this is a case where half a movie -- either half -- is apt to be better than the whole.
Two of the screenwriters, Steve Zacharias and Jeff Buhai, also wrote Revenge of the Nerds, so it's not surprising that they're more interested in tame teen-age fantasies than in social satire.
...a film that tries to be too many things at once -- funny but not campy, sad and scary, a horror story and a human tragedy...
This is a ruder, cruder version of the hip-hop movie House Party, and it offers a fascinating glimpse at the way street life enters pop culture.

Flatliners is a stylish, eerie psychological horror film laced with wit, a movie that thrives on its characters' guilty secrets and succeeds on the strength of the director Joel Schumacher's flair for just this sort of smart, unpretentious entertainment.

The Scout was directed by Michael Ritchie and written by Mr. Brooks and Monica Johnson from a script written by Andrew Bergman years ago. It's probably not all that valuable to wonder how so many talented people went so wrong.
Eerie, inventive, [and] poetic.
This exceptional film takes the makings of a limp "women's weeper" and as if by magic, spins them into gold.
movie_title: How to Make an American Quilt (1995)

movie_review_blurb: What Harry and Sally do -- the true focus of this often funny but amazingly hollow film -- is saunter through the romanticized lives of intelligent, successful, neurotic New Yorkers.
The film is dominated and destroyed by Mr. Cage's chaotic, self-indulgent performance.
The film thinks it wants to be sincere, when all it truly wants is to be popular, just like the other kids' movies, so it sells off its originality.
From characters to camera angles, this story of a self-absorbed jazz trumpeter is one long cliche, the kind that might make his most loyal admirers wince and wonder, 'Spike, what happened?'
[A] surprisingly charming film, which may be the first Christmas black comedy for children.
The film is all charming performances and grace notes, but there are plenty of worse things to be.
Mr. Crystal's style as a director is smoothe and bland.
A film whose enormous authority and intelligence extend to every detail.
In Country means to capture the deep tragedy at the center of pedestrian lives. Instead, it becomes a pedestrian film.
The film's great achievement is to reveal the relentless way in which coaches and recruiters refuse to see Arthur and William as anything other than social cliches.

The scenes move with such relentless energy and smashing special-effects extravagance that Die Hard turns out to be everything action-genre fans, and Bruce Willis's relieved investors, might have hoped for.
Movies are, after all, about fakery; so is the story of Norville's rise and fall and redemption.

Noisy and meant for children only. A bored grown-up's only consolation is that the Rangers' popularity has probably peaked, and the next kiddie phenomenon must be on the way. Don't even think about what it will cost.
movie_title: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers: The Movie (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Wigstock, the event and the movie, is good-natured, campy fun.
Mild and predictable, the very things an adventure movie should never be.
Mr. Dalton is perfectly at home as an angry Bond, and as a romantic lead and as an action hero, but he never seems to blend any two of those qualities at once.
Mr. McNaughton's observations are so chilling and precise that they gain some artistic stature even when they cross the line that makes the audience voyeurs and accomplices.
movie_title: Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer (1986)

movie_review_blurb: The film's first-time director, Peter Segal, has adopted the series' style seamlessly.
movie_title: The Naked Gun 33 1/3: The Final Insult (1994)

movie_review_blurb: A pallid film framed at the start and finish by live action and mostly composed of cheap-looking animation.
The sequel suffers from a lame, saccharine premise and a fatally earnest manner.
movie_title: Sister Act 2: Back in the Habit (1993)

movie_review_blurb: There is no mistaking the political toughness of this melodrama's message.
Like those overreaching sophomore term papers we can all laugh at now, this disappointing film may free the Hughes brothers to move on to fresher, more inspired work.
Here are two things I never thought I'd say: I like a movie about fly fishing, and Robert Redford has directed one of the most ambitious, accomplished films of the year.
It turns one man's slide toward madness into a wickedly mischievous, entertaining suspense thriller.
No other director I can think of has come as close as Bresson to molding his players into what are, in effect, variations on a continuing personality, much the way a painter might.
As surely as if it were a McDonald's or a Burger King, Beverly Hills Cop III is part of a money-making franchise, though this one has been abandoned for so long it has cobwebs on top of cobwebs.
A muddled film that takes a standard urban action movie and adds a veneer of overwrought romance.
It is possible that some children will be tickled at the very idea of a talking pig, even one as bland as Gordy. They will probably be children who have never seen any movie, ever.
This is a film with its head in the clouds, its feet on the ground and -- just often enough -- its heart on its sleeve, in which space-age special effects take second place to family emotions.
The background is energetic; too bad the foreground is just as chaotic.
One of these days, maybe Kurt Russell and Kelly McGillis will look back at Winter People and laugh.
The Baby-Sitters Club is like an average installment of the series, aimed at girls who can't get enough of their fictional friends in any form.
They take their explosives and their silly roles much too seriously.
As in his best films, here Mr. Roeg is a master of capturing the slightly off kilter sense of an apparently normal world. His camera is unobtrusive, and then suddenly it tilts a bit to jolt.
There has rarely been such a steep and strange decline between a movie and its sequel as the one between the fast, silly original and the dismal, boring Major League II.
Genuine, if bizarre, proof of Sam Raimi's talent and developing skill.
The Garbage Pail Kids Movie is enough to make you believe in strict and faraway boarding schools.
You might call this the scattershot school of film making.

It says everything about Mr. Newman's performance, the single best of this year and among the finest he has ever given, that you never stop to wonder how a guy as good-looking as Paul Newman ended up this way.
It is refreshing to see so much style and life in the old undead tale, and to watch this strong cast with its perfect deadpan attitudes.
Instead of simply assuming that the old have interesting lives, the film never stops congratulating itself for being daring enough to focus on them.
This film isn't aiming for high-toned drama, just high-energy entertainment, which is what it delivers.
Love him or hate him, Mr. Ferrara is one of the few directors who can turn genre movies into something deeper.
Starts off as an ambitious, gripping, quasi-sci-fi thriller and turns into an over-the-top mess. But it's never dull, and looking at Bradley Cooper is never bad.
Was she the Emily Dickinson of photos or the anti-Mary Poppins? This fascinating film reveals a lot about Maier's rich photos & glimpses at her bizarre, hidden personality.
Even James Franco and Natalie Portman can't save this sporadically funny, unevenly written one-joke comedy. It drops actors into Medieval times, using modern language. Ha.
Part 'Oceans 11' with Nazis, part Clooney lecturing us about art and culture. Blissfully acted but strangely flat, it shifts uncomfortably between caper and classroom lesson.
Is it a Valentine's Day prank? Gives magic and realism a bad name; doesn't make romance seem so hot either. So dull it feels like a vanity project with a Hollywood budget.
'Taken' meets 'Speed' on a plane, with a dash of Agatha Christie, but as breezily entertaining as a commercial action thriller is supposed to be. Neeson and cast make it work.
Gyllenhaal is eloquently subtle, but this muddled identity-thriller relies on misdirection and leaves you feeling not stunned, just cheated.
A survivor's story,a political statement and an eloquent meditation on images and memory. The miniatures and the film are exquisite works of art infused with living memory
A brilliant, magical combination: pure Jarmusch and entirely new. It's visually sumptuous, but his droll attitude remains in this wry story of perfectly cast vampires in love.
Bold and entertaining, this is not as sleek or clever as X-Men:First Class, but makes up for those lapses with McAvoy's fiercely emotional performance and dazzling set pieces.
Jenison's obsession is the basis for a playful,entertaining film. I wasn't convinced for a millisecond by his wackadoodle theory, but I enjoyed every minute of Tim's Vermeer.
'Groundhog Day Meets Alien.' Relatively good compared to Cruise's recent, unwatchable movies because Liman orchestrates spectacular action; the talking scenes are tiresome.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Does Haggis actually believe that this pretentious, simplistic film has any substance? An overwrought, vapid three-strand story, each thread more banal than the last.
The film resembles a genius' workshop filled with old-fashioned toys.Gondry's visual imagination is so sparkling,it hardly matters that the whimsy overhwhelms the characters.
The film should have been a roller coaster ride; instead, watching it is like trudging through a swamp.
Terry Gilliam's listless and shallow futuristic fantasy lands like a pale evocation of his classic "Brazil."
On paper, this lyrical, black-and-white rendering of Lincoln's backwoods boyhood may seem pompous, but it is beautiful, poetic and graceful, with its own flowing rhythm.
Eye-opening but never didactic, Sissako's beautifully shot film immerses us in a reality we usually experience as no more than a headline.
Mostly there is extraordinary photography, a palette of dusty gray tones that echo the faded look of 19th-century photographs.
Michod's arresting and tense film -- part thriller, part warning of dystopia -- is played with ferocious restraint by Guy Pearce.
An absorbing work of historical preservation and strong ideas.
With a conventional style,the film puts us in the center of a relentless, fatal battle in Afghanistan. Lone Survivor will make you squirm, but earns every wrenching minute.
Never quite lets you forget you're watching bravura acting but that acting is deliriously funny. The film is just enough over the top so the artifice becomes part of the joke.
Sounds unlikely, but Brad Pitt + Zombies = Dull in this self-defeating, formulaic action film.
Warm, engaging, and thoroughly charming even though we can predict every turn in this old-fashioned coming of age story. Carell is terrific as an unlikable bully.
Galvanizing, tense gritty-indie, brilliantly acted by Jordan and Spencer. Very much worth watching even though the too-neat, manipulative screenplay undercuts it artistically.
Gosling and Scott Thomas elevate this stylish midnight movie but not enough to overcome its emptiness. More camp and cult than art; sometimes silly and gross but never boring.
Witty about social pretensions, eloquent about failure & loss, acerbic about family, Allen's light-handed tragedy is a major work. Blanchett is dazzling as the fragile heroine.
Audience-pandering History Lite. Whitaker is dazzling, but Daniels' self-congratulatory film spoon-feeds us a civil rights lesson without adding nuance to the conversation.
Poetic, operatic, historically sweeping, as lush and seductive as Wong's previous films. Don't think of it as a kung fu movie; think of it as the work of a master filmmaker.
There is something hilarious about a journalistic doofus like Ron Burgundy creating cable news. Ferrell & McKay are silly-smart. Not pointed satire but ridiculously funny.
So sharply directed, tautly edited, rich and believably acted by Jackman and Gyllenhaal that you quickly forgive its tired story. An intense, satisfying thriller.
A thrilling action movie, with its fairy tale princess updated to a contemporary superheroine. Wright's action never flags and Ronan is suburbly natural. Totally satisfying.
All is Bright is unsugary, a small out-of-season miracle.
A galvanizing documentary with rare first-hand perspectives. With great immediacy, Noujaim provides a smart eye-opening view as activists maneuver toward an uncertain future.
An amazing film, at once happy, sad and exhilarating to watch. Told in an elegant pattern of present-day and flashbacks,full of music that suits every graceful shift in tone.
If you're going to tell a heart-warming story about a sweet wronged little old lady,it helps to have a witty,cynical journalist along. Dench & Coogan create a perfect balance.
Bale is nuanced & affecting in an overloaded, overcalculated film that doesn't deserve him. The characters' problems seem orchestrated by Screenwriting 101 rather than fate.
Thompson is so delightfully acerbic and convincing that she makes Saving Mr. Banks safe for people who find Disney films too saccharine. Not adventurous, but entertaining.
Franco's powerful adaptation, directed with discipline and intelligence, captures McCarthy's mordant darkness. It reveals the humanity buried beneath animalistic behavior.
Even as you tick off the film's overload of references, though -- a Matrix here, a James Bond there -- the amazing effects and Cobb's quest carry you along.
Suicide Squad looked bright and promising in its run-up, but lands on the screen with a big-budget thud of missed opportunities.
The actors make these characters vivid, within a structure that is recognisably Malick's.
No need to resist this enchanting, airy trifle with a surprisingly sober twist.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Endearingly funny.
As a girl just beginning to recognize her sexual power, [Emma] Roberts moves one step closer to adult stardom.
Streep's performance saves the film from its own heavy-handedness.
Visually sumptuous though it is, this is a brilliantly nuanced, psychologically complex story about obsession, love, control and surrender, all cloaked in a sophisticated Gothic romance.
With harrowing realism, The Company Men captures the raw, personal impact of the economic meltdown.

George Hickenlooper's fact-based satire, starring Kevin Spacey and his ever-sharp comic timing, offers an antic version of the wheeler-dealer whose ambition and blinkered morality were close to caricature all along.
Robbie makes Tonya so sympathetic that it's easy to gloss over the film's major flaws.
Iñárritu's trademark interwoven plots have one thread too many here, but this shattering experience-earthbound and fraught with the afterlife-is worth every undying minute.

The American doesn't set out to be anything other than a twisty, deliberate film that relies on suspense and paranoia more than car chases and gunplay. The problem is that even on its own artsy terms, the film falls apart long before the end.
In the great tradition of summer popcorn hits, Angelina Jolie's action-spy thriller Salt is stupid but fun.

This endlessly fascinating swirl of a film could have come only from Nolan, who blends the cerebral twistiness of Memento (his thriller that moves backward in time) with the spectacular action of his Batman megahit, The Dark Knight.
The use of poetry suggests depth and history beyond the immediate moment, even when the characters, called only He and She, trade epithets as lovers in the midst of horrifying anger can.
The film's wit and layered sense of history seem richer than ever.

Think of the film's segments as high-art Webisodes and you see how pertinent Potter is to the topsy-turvy world of filmmaking today, how smoothly she blends the -cutting edge and the mainstream, how underappreciated she has been.
Red Sparrow sounds as if it has a foolproof recipe: sex, spies and Russia. But the only way to make sense of this thudding, clichéd would-be thriller is to think of it as an unintentional comedy.
Director Darren Aronofsky's darkly enthralling entertainment makes the perfect antidote to too many sugary holiday Nutcrackers.
Richard E. Robbins's straightforward Operation Homecoming has enlightening moments as it presents writing by American soldiers who have served in Iraq and Afghanistan.
movie_title: America At A Crossroads: Operation Homecoming: Writing The Wartime Experience (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Charles Ferguson's gripping No End in Sight relies on former Bush administration officials to make the case that in its earliest stages the American military operation in Iraq was catastrophically mismanaged.
Gracefully weaving together interviews (some with the soldiers convicted of the beating), fresh images and official photographs, it suggests why so many politically themed fiction films have failed.
The film sets itself apart from the average adventure saga by assuming a pointed cultural perspective.

In a perfect cinematic universe, every sequel would be like The Godfather Part II... In the Marvel Cinematic Universe, there is Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2, which coasts pleasantly enough on familiarity and a few bright new touches.
The character of Wonder Woman enters the almost exclusively male domain of DC comics movies... Under this pressure, Jenkins comes through with a work that radiates confidence and sangfroid.
In a swift 106 minutes, watching Dunkirk becomes a stunning and genuine experience, enveloping viewers in a way few movies ever do.
As powerful a film as this year is likely to see.
Jolie has put her stardom to stunning artistic use.
The film's message is empowering but its subtext is more fascinating, as Gaga puts her take-charge philosophy to use.
Underneath the vibrancy of Moonee's spirit, Baker delivers a heavy-handed statement about the fraudulent hopes offered by Disney magic, and the way so many American dreams have been shattered.
Iannucci masterfully blends dark humour about an authoritarian regime and farcical comedy performed with perfect timing.
Soup is... the perfect word to describe this pretentious mess of a film. It is full of vapid characters and overwrought imagery, which Aronofsky seems to think add up to allegory.
By the end, Nina's quest for perfection-and Portman's blazing performance-will leave you breathless.

Ford doesn't enliven the film for nostalgic reasons. He brings fierce, potent energy to the role, capturing Deckard's suspicion of K, protectiveness about his past, and will to survive. In a career of iconic roles, this is among his best.
But all the silliness reminds us that there is no age limit on expressing your confident inner vixen - especially in these uneasy times.
With [Matt] Damon, they share something more exciting than looks: a slow-burning intelligence that leaves us feeling both unsettled and seduced.
Director Jane Campion's most enthralling film since The Piano.
Lady Bird may sound slight, but it offers an eloquent, fresh voice from a thoroughly accomplished film-maker.
Sicko is wildly comic while tearing apart the country's health care system.
Predictable action crushes character & story. If all you want is blockbuster action it's there and Cavill wins Best Looking Superman. If you want more revisit a Dark Knight.
Hugely entertaining, the film walks the line between hilarious kitsch & character study. Douglas' performance is brilliant, sympathetic, an act of impeccable mimicry & depth.
Gravity comes loaded with technical wizardry, but Cuaron's visceral, dynamic story-telling is the film's most magical special effect. He makes outer space seem intimate.
This beautifully textured drama about a man caught between two cultures reflects the distrust, misunderstanding and harsh political reality of Pakistan-American relations.
Despite an occasional gleam in Depp's eye, this is something you'd never associate with Thompson:sluggish. Robinson directs so earnestly it might be A Portrait of the Artist.
Maggio's film may be small, but it's full of texture.
movie_title: The Last Rites of Joe May (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's not Leo's fault, but this shallow, conventional biopic is a snooze. On the Eastwood scale closer to Flags of Our Fathers - Serious, Important, Dull - than masterful.
Haunting and urgent.Herzog's tough-minded film takes an uncompromising stand against the death penalty,but goes beyond to look at the larger issue of crime and blighted lives
Clooney is brilliant as the emotionally jolted hero of Payne's droll yet immensely moving film. In its perfectly wrought eloquence, it may be the best film of the year.
Williams is a wonder, Redmayne terrific but this sharp film is less about Monroe than about a cultural moment: fame, movie pr, Olivier's old-school acting vs. Method.
DiCaprio is wonderful but can't save this misbegotten film, which is tethered to Fitzgerald's words while failing to approach "Gatsby"'s romantic, heartbreaking soul.
Sometimes amusing but too familiar - from yesterday's facts to a Michael Moore-ish structure - the doc does create a convincing portrait of Palin as the ultimate Mean Girl.
Lower your expectations.Scene for scene, effectively intense, with fierce performances, but McQueen sets up a narrative and never follows through.Why are these people damaged?
Not a celebrity vanity project, but an astute, dramatically gripping, deeply feminist work. Despite some script problems, the film is a surprising triumph in so many ways.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Spielberg still knows how to make a crowd-pleasing blockbuster, but this sweeping, comfortably old-fashioned WWI cliche has the soul of a hollow chocolate Santa.
Mr. Goldblum, Ms. Baker and Mr. Bates (in a relatively small role) all seem professional, restrained and uncomfortable, which is at least a tribute to their good sense.
This walloping(literally; everybody gets walloped) spy-action movie is built around Carano, but the real fun comes from the international adventure and dream supporting cast.
Close is unconvincing as a man,but accept the premise and the character's strength,bravery and heartbreaking sadness come through. McTeer is amazing in Garcia's eloquent film.
A beautifully-shot, disappointing mess. Riseborough is brilliant as Wallis Simpson, but Wally (Cornish) is as ludicrous a character as you'll see on screen this year.
Witherspoon, Pine or Hardy could carry a film alone. Together the results are three times worse in McG's flat,cobbled-together action-romance.
Not as surprising as the original, but every bit as much fun: a popcorn detective movie in Victorian clothes, with high-tech action and droll humor.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Sophisticated and hugely entertaining, with Pitt and Hill an unlikely but terrific buddy team. A delight even for someone who knows and cares next to nothing about baseball.
Gosling's amazing, subtle performance - body language, a glance of his eyes - turns this psychologically charged action movie into more than a genre piece.
Soderbergh is always intriguing, but this plague thriller should have been more than an all-star health warning. The banal screenplay suits some cheapo cable movie.
Elegant and haunting despite a sometimes didactic screenplay, far from the history lesson disguised as a movie I'd read about. McAvoy is amazing, fierce and thoughtul.
A would-be romantic drama as lumbering as an elephant. Pattinson and Witherspoon have lost their usual sparkle; a tedious film, with leaden direction and a charmless script.
Small and slight, the kind of blithe little relationship film that feels more European than American. An enjoyable bauble.
Ferrell gives a performance most dramatic actors could only dream of - restrained, nuanced, enormously moving - in this uneven yet finally eloquent little indie.
An irredeemably lame by-the-numbers romcom. The plot is creaky, the ending obvious, the Goodwin-Hudson friendship so flat and false they might be fighting over a Ken doll.
Gibson is powerful, touching in Foster's finely shaped, offbeat drama as a profoundly sad man trying to save himself. The haunting fictional portrait lingers beyond the film.
Glorious, sophisticated, very funny. Allen knowingly toys with romanticism as Manhattan meets Purple Rose of Cairo, with Paris and the 20's instead of NY and the Depression.
Bangkok may be bigger, sexier, sleazier than Vegas, but this sequel feels tired and cautious. Ed Helms does everything he can to make a not very funny film work.
Like a too-faithful adaptation afraid to tweak the novel, this pleasant Spielberg-adoring nostalgia-fest is easier to admire than to love. It's borrowed magic.
All the glowing green bolts of light may be enough for a summer action film, but can't disguise the soulless, by-the-numbers approach. And Reynolds' hero has no personality.
The funniest film since The Hangover. The ideal cast makes the outlandish premise work in this silly, clever summer comedy, as shrewdly played and hilarious as they come.
A thinking woman's fairy tale. Breillat explores sexual awakening, and the meaning of class and gender, revising the classic story while keeping its beauty and charm.
This rich, graceful film is like seeing Rowling's novels through a shimmering, magic mirror. A magnificent, nearly-flawless finale, warmly emotional without being sentmental.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The homogenized, bland hero belongs in a Barbie Dream House, not a war. He's a cipher at the center of big-budget action that is cartoony, 3-D but never engaging.
Warm and hilarious, a kaleidoscope of romantic misadventures with Gosling,of all people, as it freshest, funniest character.
The suberb Weisz almost single-handedly carries this disjointed movie and its weighty theme, but can't disguise the way The Whistleblower is easily reduced to a noble message.
No artistic ambition, but the film is an even more effective, big warm bath of a crowd-pleaser than the megaselling novel. Davis and Spencer raise the maids above caricature.
De Niro's fullest role and strongest performance in years as a proud, self-deluded writer on a relentless downward spiral. A reminder that De Niro is still the best.
This Spanish-language spoof of bad old Western movies is like a looser, goofier version of a Christopher Guest film.
Thoroughly enchanting. Transports us into a magical world of movies, yet looks forward in its embrace of dreams and imagination. The first truly artistic use of 3D I've seen.
Don't be put off by its hokey-sounding subject: this unexpectedly powerful, subtle little film is exquisitely made, enormously moving and politically-charged.
Sam Mendes adds freshness in this smart, character-driven film, as middle-aged Bond thrives in today's terror-ridden world. Still loaded with action, the best Bond in years.
Knightley and Taylor-Johnson are so passionless they might was well be animatronic. The theatrical conceit is more stunt than inspiration, the film cold as a Russian winter.
The title is the only clunky thing in this smart, witty film. Cooper & Lawrence find the balance between being likable and making us queasy. De Niro & Weaver are miraculous.
Full of 3D wonders, but in the end no more than an easygoing, unchallenging adventure movie. Ang Lee is a master whose films can be emotionally powerful; Life of Pi isn't.
A disappointing, derivative noir that gets its spark from Pitt and Gandolfini's performances. Slight and pulpy, but it's aiming for arty and trenchant.
Thank goodness for Martin Freeman, who makes Bilbo a feeling person & a hobbit. Otherwise, the film is so awed by its technical ingenuity that character and story fade away.
Totally fascinating and unexpected. No bravura filmmaking here, but rich, often startling observations about anti-terrorism, torture and the amorality of it all.
Washington may save a planeload of people, but he can't save this manipulative, predictable, cliched film, so typical of Zemeckis' sturdy, unoriginal style. A well-made sham.
Sumptuous-looking, crisply directed, wonderfully cast and far wittier than the drippy, earnest Twilight Saga. A captivating tale with a tongue-in-cheek sense of play.
The rapturous responses seem over-the-top for this modest, entertaining,visually clever film. The fun is arguing with its subjects' looney theories; rewatch The Shining first.
This triptych about fathers, sons and the determinism of class is two-thirds of a terrific film. The last part is a letdown because the first are so powerfully believable.
Boyle is always worth paying attention to, and McAvoy is captivting, but this twisty film is a stylish disappoint with a long, dull middle section.
An offbeat little gem of a black-comedy that plays much better than it sounds. The deft screenplay and straight-faced comic actors make a familar premise feel fresh.
This may be Malick's most diasppointing film. Art at its purest, but with hollow characters and cliched images, not the best example of an art or Malick film you'll ever see.
A slick, vapid thriller. Cronenberg has style and flair, but his all-too-obvious ideas about fame leave us with caricatures, not characters.
A sharp, enticing psychological cat-and-mouse game. Its gleeful dark wit comes from manipulations, voyeurism, the idea that we all invade each other's lives and thoughts.
Lawrence is terrific, but the film is a sleek, competent example of a big-budget, sure-fire commercial hit without much soul or style.
Promised Land tries hard to win you over but finally wears you down with its sincerity.
This Oz doesn't have much heart or wonder, but with appealing characters, terrific actors and colorful action, it's an entertaining fantasy for the moment.
I admire the film's terrific acting and ability to draw you into its lurid world, but Daniels is daring to the point of wrong-headedness. This is pulp, which wants to be more.
Might have been a one-note joke, but Wexler, Dancy and Gyllenhaal make it a witty, slyly feminist comedy of sexual manners.
No one has an eye or sensibility like Anderson's, but this is a chilly disappointment. The unaffecting kids are meant to be the emotional center, yet the adults steal the film.
Can Pattinson act without fangs? Not so much. As a social climber and 19th c. gigolo, his robotic acting matches the stately direction, which negates the sexy, messy theme.
Fonda's clever casting and good-humored performance can't save this clunky, obvious mess - ludicrous from its contrived premise on. A waste of Beresford and the actors.
Not a sci-fi movie but a droll, totally charming, un-hokey romantic comedy about two misfits. The film belongs to Aubrey Plaza's deadpan, touching, understated performance.
A sunny, charming apocalypse film that overcomes its contrived premise. Even the off-beat pairing of Steve Carell and Keira Knightley works better than you'd imagine.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The high-concept joke fades fast in this Abe-meets-vampires mashup, saddled with clunky 3-D, a lame screenplay, and actors as stiff as the statue at the Lincoln Memorial.
You don't have to know the 60's afternoon soap to fall for this funny pop confection, but you do need to appreciate its light, spoofy tone. If you do, it's a ghoulish joy.
Slick and vapid, with characters worse than stick figures. In the age of 'Breaking Bad,' Stone's action-rush about drugs and violence just seems old.
When clever meets silly in this political spoof, silly always wins, but the cartoonish exaggeration works with some swift, perfectly timed comedy.
Affleck's thoughtul, extremely entertaining film shifts easily from the threatening to the comic, capturing the odd mix of fear and absurdity that informs the national mood.
Smart and stylized - which doesn't innoculate this story of a sad billionaire against lethal familiarity and dullness. Pattinson's stiffness works, but the dialogue is vapid.
West is so underused, he barely gets to raise an eyebrow in this watchable but pedestrian film, with Hall ghostbusting in a Downton Abbey setting. Cliched and never chilling.
Inspired by The Big Chill, Canet's appealing homage makes deja vu seem like a good thing. His warm ensemble piece engages us right through to its final visceral punch.
A shrewd satisfying thriller with a magical twist in Gere's performance. Instead of a demonized tycoon - Bernie Madoff as Satan - we see a fully-realized character.
Intelligent, chilly and fascinating, this uneven film didn't need 70 mm. It's a taut eye-to-eye war between Hoffman, magnificent as an egotist, and Phoenix, his needy follower
Neurosis hasn't seemed this adorably sane since Woody Allen. Clever, funny, expertly walking the line between arty and mainstream, Ruby Sparks is a lovable romantic comedy.
Rock and roll is at its core and by default not meant to be neutral, but Jarmusch does an excellent job at steering the narrative as objectively as possible.

This is a satisfyingly sober thriller, almost melancholy in tone - and as morally complex as a John Le Carré novel.
It goes on and on, and just when you think you can't take any more insufferably trite good intentions, it keeps on going.
What an effective calling card for debut writer-director Patrick Hughes this is - if not for the Australian tourist board.
Who knows, we might be looking at the evolution of the guilty-pleasure movie - padded out with top-drawer talent to spare audience blushes.
Possibly it ought to come with a warning: contains traces of smugness.

Melodramatic soap opera.

A delirious London nightmare that might be overcooked, pretentious even, but is nonetheless beguilingly imaginative and genuinely scary in places.

Bollywood golden couple Aishwarya Rai and Abhishek Bachchan star in this absurdly extravagant melodrama, rife with cliches, song-and-dance showstoppers, macho action sequences and lush tourist board-approved landscapes.

Rock fronts this informative rummage through the $9 billion US black hair industry in a style much like his stand-up comedy: hilarious, insightful and charming enough to let him get away with the flammable stuff.

movie_review_blurb: The story is a bit tangled, and there is too much of it packed into nearly 80 minutes, but little kids won't be bothered when the animation is so magical.
